title: It's Eras but not as we know it.....
content:
Help, I’m being incredibly lazy and don’t want to tweak about 80 letters for clients new ridiculously long company name changes.  
Basically, I’m after Eras but without the 2˚ slant and especially without the curve.... any clues ... anyone??? Or am I just completely clueless. Many thanks in advance.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013110002im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/skell_5717.jpg)

 [‹ Stella McCartney logo](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013110002/http:/www.typophile.com/node/4801 "Go to previous forum topic") [Font ID Please? Lend me your wisdom... ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013110002/http:/www.typophile.com/node/45398 "Go to next forum topic")
author: RedSquare

comments.content:
There was a version of Eras without the slant from back in th 90s that came with some (ancient low-res) printers. Not sure if it’s still available, or what printer brand it was.

- Lex

That face could be Delta Jaeger not Eras?  
 [http://www.fonts.com/findfonts/detail.htm?pid=423461&grab\_id=0&page\_id=1...](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013110002/http:/www.fonts.com/findfonts/detail.htm?pid=423461&grab_id=0&page_id=11690&query=delta%20jaeger&SCOPE=Fonts "http://www.fonts.com/findfonts/detail.htm?pid=423461&grab\_id=0&page\_id=11690&query=delta%20jaeger&SCOPE=Fonts")

The cuts in Delta Jaeger’s ’P’ and ’R’ go the wrong way, and the bottom of the ’E’ and ’L’ are angled.

- Lex
